heading: Mark McGowan seeks Perth Stadium funding help from AFL, Canberra

profiles.name: Daniel Emerson
profiles.biography: Daniel started with The West Australian as a cadet in 2005 after cutting his teeth at Community Newspapers. He covered courts, online news and state politics before a period of travel including a stint at the Sydney Morning Herald. He rejoined The West's State politics team and has been president of the West Australian press gallery since 2011. He's covered four federal and two WA elections.

homepageHead: McGowan seeks AFL, Canberra support for stadium
homepageTeaser: Premier looks for contributions to the $1.45 billion cost of the new Perth Stadium

mainImages.captionText: The new Perth Stadium from East Perth.
The new Perth Stadium from East Perth.

mainVideo.videoDescription: Premier Mark McGowan has gone cap in hand to the AFL and the Federal Government for contributions to the $1.45 billion capital cost of the new Perth Stadium.

blocks.text: Premier Mark McGowan has gone cap in hand to the AFL and the Federal Government for contributions to the $1.45 billion capital cost of the new Perth Stadium, arguing WA deserves the same support given to interstate facilities.

The intervention is set to revive a sore point from last year’s Federal election when Malcolm Turnbull and Bill Shorten matched each other’s $100 million pledges to Townsville Stadium in the clutch seat of Herbert, only for the Prime Minister to fly to WA the next day and wave away questions about funding Perth Stadium.
The West Australian can reveal Mr McGowan wrote to Mr Turnbull and WA Treasurer Ben Wyatt wrote to AFL boss Gillon McLachlan this month seeking unspecified contributions towards construction costs.

The AFL will be the anchor tenant of Perth Stadium, which is on track to open for next year’s football season, and Mr McGowan declared during this year’s State election campaign that he would not be “too proud” to ask the code to help pay for the state-of-the-art facility.
“Recently the Federal Government and the AFL have provided significant funding contributions to other stadia developments around the country,” he said yesterday.
“I don’t see why WA should be missing out. I’d prefer I didn’t have to go asking for a contribution at this late stage, however, with the way the State’s finances are, I have no choice.”

blocks.text: The State Government has pointed to the AFL’s recent contribution of $10 million to the $65 million redevelopment of Greater Western Sydney’s Spotless Stadium, comprising 15 per cent of the total cost, and $4 million to Geelong’s $90 million Simonds Stadium redevelopment.

It also highlighted Federal Government contributions to Adelaide Oval ($55 million), Skilled Stadium ($24 million), the SCG ($75 million), the MCG ($90 million) and the $100 million commitment to the $250 million Townsville Stadium.
AFL spokesman Patrick Keane indicated the league had a track record of contributing to stadium renovations rather than new builds.
“Our history is that the AFL contributes to those venues across the country that have been redeveloped where we play our AFL matches,” he said. “We will engage in discussions with the Government.”
Mr Turnbull’s office declined to comment.

blocks.text: Shadow WA sports minister John McGrath said the Opposition would welcome any interstate funding but that it must come “without any catches”.
“The stadium must remain under the control and ownership of Western Australians,” he said.

Mr McGrath said the State Government needed to identify what any funding would be used for. “Will it go into any future costs of the stadium, will it be used to retire debt or does the Government intend for (it) to go to a completely separate infrastructure project,” he said.
